text: you know first there's just that sense
of disbelief that you actually have
prostate cancer because i think you know
when you hear about people having
serious diseases you always think it's
going to be the other guy my name is
Dana Jennings I'm 51 years old i live in
Montclair New Jersey with my wife dead
and when my son's drew you knowin I've
been an editor here at the time since
1993 but even though I'm a times editor
I'm also a writer I'm writing this these
weekly blog posts for The Times about
having prostate cancer and coping with
it and I think really what happened that
by me by me being willing to to be blunt
and honest about having prostate cancer
really gave this a group of men and
women permission to talk about things
that's I don't think any of them had
talked about and literally i feel as if
since that first post went up on
november 11th that my that my life has
changed you like it like anyone who gets
a serious illness or disease yeah i feel
more thankful than ever for for what i
do have you know my wife and my sons you
know my my wife Deb is is is great she's
the one who takes the notes during our
doctors visits she's the one ferreting
information out of the internet and from
other doctors it allows a measure of
control I don't think that there's any
chance I'll ever have the capacity
myself to come up with a cure and so I
do what I can make him happy make them
comfortable and you know that involves a
lot of things when you're a couple you
these things can either bring you can
either split you apart or make you you
know bring you closer together and it's
definitely brought us closer together
sex becomes very weird you know I'll be
totally honest since since my surgery
on july seventh i haven't had an
erection you know I've certainly been
aroused you have to redefine you know
what your ideas of sex and sexuality are
you know sure it would be it would be
great to have you know normal sex but my
wife and I are still close you know it
stinks but it is what it is and there is
kind of a Twilight Zone aspect to it
it's just I've always tried to have a
sense of humor I think if you can't
temper your life with that that you're
you're going to spend a lot of time
really really depressed on Halloween Deb
and I were driving down to the cancer
institute of new jersey for what i think
the first time in my life I see a casket
truck on the road I just you know if you
believed in omens you know you I would
have told my wife just to turn the car
back around and let's go home we were
hungry just bear his last I think we
really connect when it comes to
listening to music together and that's
what I've been like one of greatest
things that he's given me as my love
immunity the night they drove Old Dixie
dan I my dad cannot sing like I said
before he is probably the bigger biggest
music lover that I know and his he can't
carry tune it's it's horrendous
you know where you're in the hospital
you got lot you know you're here is kind
of long and it gets greasy and slimy so
I said all right I'm getting a buzz cut
your usual right yeah even if it's not
real it makes me feel more energetic and
it makes me feel more ready to face the
world each day it also made me feel 10
years old again you know like I was you
know back home in New Hampshire playing
baseball and reading comic books and
watching the Red Sox you know when I get
a buzz cut it's it's like Batman putting
on his mask
I'll be getting my treatments five days
a week I'll have 33 treatments and all
this is the unfairly moment coming up
pardon me it's not a direct beam it's
not like it's not like a James Bond
movie where he's chained at the table
you know I'm in the machine the
radiation machine the radiations coming
down and suddenly I just hear those
chords dum dum dum
he like heavy metal and he likes really
loud music I played it for him and he
just decided that iron man like Sabbath
that was going to be his son it's what
it's what personal medicine should be
about you know just just that little
just that little human touch you know
I'm a naturally optimistic person but
I'm also realistic I'm kind of that odd
thing I'm kind of a dreamy pragmatist I
know this is serious and I worry I mean
I
I cry
you know I worry that that I won't see
my son's get married or see my
grandchildren I mean and it's not so
much for me as it is for them you know
in one hand if 51 years is a long time
you know the world has changed a lot
since the nineteen fifty-seven and I'm
happy with my life but there's also that
you know that deep part of me that wants
those things
